title: Irregularities, Delays, and Corruption in the Procurement and Distribution of Smart Driving Licenses
description:
The Government of Nepal, through the Department of Transport Management (DoTM), initiated a project to replace paper-based driving licenses with electronic smart cards. The project was part of an Information and Communication Technology (ICT) initiative funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). An agreement was signed with Madras Security Printers Pvt. Ltd. (MSP) of India in October 2013 to develop the system and supply cards and hardware, with distribution beginning in December 2015.

From its inception, the project has been marred by severe issues, including chronic delays, persistent technical failures, supply chain disruptions, and allegations of widespread corruption. The system's failures have resulted in massive backlogs, at times exceeding 800,000 applicants, forcing citizens to wait for months or even over a year to receive their licenses after passing all required tests.

The problems have been attributed to multiple factors:

  • Faulty Technology: The software developed by MSP was reportedly buggy and incomplete, and the provided printers were slow and prone to breakdowns.
  • Contractual Disputes: Frequent disputes between the DoTM and its contractors paralyzed operations. In one instance, MSP allegedly attempted to extort an additional $40,000 from the DoTM, relenting only after the department threatened blacklisting.
  • Substandard Supplies: Another contractor, Malika Incorporated, was found to have printed substandard cards that faded over time, forcing a halt to their use.

A major corruption scandal emerged when an internal DoTM probe revealed that between 2015 and 2023, over 102,000 smart licenses were issued illegally to individuals who had not passed the mandatory exams. This was allegedly achieved by exploiting vulnerabilities in the Electronic Driving License and Vehicle Registration System (EDLVRS). Consequently, the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) and the Central Investigation Bureau (CIB) of the Nepal Police have launched major investigations, targeting numerous current and former DoTM employees.
unverified_info:
Several pieces of information related to this case are unconfirmed or lack precise details:

  • A September 2022 report claimed the DoTM had paid 90% of a Rs 700 billion contract amount to Madras Security Printers. This figure is exceptionally high and is widely believed to be a reporting error, possibly meaning Rs 700 million. The exact total value of all contracts with MSP over the years remains unclear.
  • In early 2021, the DoTM reportedly entered into an agreement with an unnamed French company to procure 1.4 million cards. This deal allegedly ran into 'personalization' problems as the new cards were not compatible with the existing software provided by MSP. It is unconfirmed which company secured this contract.
  • A German company, Muhlbauer ID Services GmbH, reportedly secured a contract worth Rs 190 million to provide 120,000 smart cards. This led to complications when MSP, the original contractor, initially refused to personalize cards from a different manufacturer.
  • The 55th Annual Report of the Auditor General noted an irregularity regarding the license's validity period. The smart cards were procured with a 10-year warranty, but the driving license itself is only valid for 5 years as per Nepali law, indicating a mismatch in procurement specifications and a potential waste of funds.
key_allegations: Illegal issuance of over 102,000 smart licenses to individuals who did not pass mandatory tests.
Corruption and exploitation of vulnerabilities within the Electronic Driving License and Vehicle Registration System (EDLVRS).
Gross mismanagement and maladministration leading to chronic delays and a public service delivery crisis.
Procurement of faulty software, slow printers, and substandard materials from contractors.
Contractual malpractice, including alleged blackmail by a contractor to extract additional payments.
related_entities: Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport
Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA)

timeline.title: Agreement Signed with Madras Security Printers
timeline.description: The Department of Transport Management (DoTM) signs an agreement with Madras Security Printers (MSP) of India to develop software and supply smart driving licenses, funded by an ADB grant.

timeline.title: Smart License Distribution Begins
timeline.description: The distribution of smart licenses officially starts, beginning at the Ekantakuna transport office in Lalitpur, Bagmati Zone.

timeline.title: License Issuance Halted Due to Technical Failures
timeline.description: DoTM halts the issuance of smart licenses from the Ekantakuna office due to a range of technical glitches with the software, including 'migration mismatch and total failure'.

timeline.title: Major Flaws Identified in Issued Licenses
timeline.description: Reports emerge that the smart licenses being issued contain serious flaws, such as incorrect categorization and missing information about the issuing authority.

timeline.title: New Contract Awarded to MSP
timeline.description: DoTM awards a new contract to Madras Security Printers to supply an additional 750,000 smart cards and three printing machines for approximately $980,000.

timeline.title: License Backlog Surpasses 200,000
timeline.description: It is reported that the backlog of unprinted smart licenses has reached over 200,000, with some applicants waiting since August 2017.

timeline.title: Printing Halted Due to Substandard Cards
timeline.description: DoTM stops printing licenses after discovering that contractor Malika Incorporated produced substandard cards using a thermal printing method that caused the text to fade.

timeline.title: Auditor General Notes Unusable Printers
timeline.description: The 57th Annual Report of the Auditor General highlights that smart card printers purchased in 2013 and 2017 are unusable due to the unavailability of spare parts.

timeline.title: DoTM Publicly Blames Contractor for Failures
timeline.description: DoTM publicly blames Madras Security Printers for persistent technical issues, stating the company failed to provide adequate support despite receiving 90% of its payment.

timeline.title: Internal Report Reveals Massive Illegal License Distribution
timeline.description: A DoTM internal report submitted to the CIAA accuses seven employees of involvement in the illegal issuance of 102,711 smart licenses over an eight-year period.

timeline.title: Contractor Relents After Blacklisting Threat
timeline.description: Madras Security Printers agrees to personalize 120,000 cards from another manufacturer after initially refusing and demanding an extra $40,000. MSP backed down after the Transport Minister ordered the DoTM to threaten blacklisting.

timeline.title: CIAA Investigation Nears Completion
timeline.description: The CIAA announces that its investigation into the distribution of over 100,000 fake licenses is in its final stage, with around 350 DoTM employees under scrutiny.
